page.title: 02Hope End Hotel
page.content: The poetess Elizabeth Barret Browning spent the greater part of her life at the estate of Hope End, an unusual name which means 'the house at the end of the valley'.She may well have felt that the estate was aptly named, since her life there was was very unhappy, mainly due to her cruel father, and a serious spinal injury from a riding accident.The house had ample grounds. It lay empty for a long time in this century and was rescued from total dereliction. It is now a country hotel. An unusual feature of the outbuildings is that a previous owner had them embellished with Moorish turrets and minarets - this was done at a time when it was in vogue to have exotic architectural features on an estate. They certainly give the outbuildings a distinct Eastern feel.
